So you guys have always said that the Officeworks so the SME side of things has always been a pretty good proxy for the economy in terms of when they come in, start spending again. Can you comment in terms of how you've seen trade in there over the past couple of months, looking into the ship?

I am not sure we've said it's a great proxy for the economy. Clearly, the small business sector is one that is very exposed to sentiment and very exposed to sharp shifts in spend. What we've seen in the last little while is a pleasing return to some confidence. And we're seeing better results in the direct business segment, which is pleasing us.

That's come about not just because of confidence. I think we're doing some very good things in there after having to disrupt our sales in one sense to actually reset the strategy and have one business offer. And we had to also get rid of some very unproductive discounting and very unproductive selling techniques.

And Mark Ward and the team have done a very good job there. And we expect to see some modest growth in the BusinessDirect sector as we go forward with a combination of what we're doing and a combination of a lift in SME confidence. But I would caution there that it is a very volatile and very exposed segment and if things tweak the other way you can expect that they will cut back spend very sharply.

. And thanks. And just one more – few more questions on Coles, and Ian, if I could. Can you just give us a sort of a little bit of commentary just in terms around category performance? I know you've sort of given some numbers or guidance previous that are fresh and private label.

Yeah, we're seeing good growth in private label as I intimated previously. That goes back to the fact that the consumer is becoming more value conscious. The areas that relate to in-home dining really, are performing above average.

So things like rice and pasta and cooking sauce as I mentioned before, we've seen growth in those particular areas. We're starting to see some signs of improvement in the fresh food categories as well, particularly on fruit and veg.
So across the organization we're seeing steady improvements coming through. And I think that's reflected in the basket growth that we are getting and the improvement in customer transactions.

And also just in terms of the extent of the price investment, I know last year you sort of quantified and said you didn't invest around 100 million in price over the period. Can you give us I suppose a better feel for this the extent to which you're investing in price at the moment and I suppose the extent to which you feel you're going to have to do that more so going forward?

Well, I think it's quite – I mean you got to look at – it's different in different categories. And I think that we've just got to focus on making sure that we improve overall value. I have not put a number on it. Again you got a gross and net number in terms of transactional differences between individual parts of our business. But I guess a good indication of the level of investment is indicative in the inflation numbers, which have actually – we've actually had a slower rate of inflation this quarter that we had the previous one.
And you expect the inflation to continue to ease as we get towards the end of the year?

Well, I think that it's been – in our numbers it's been anywhere between two and 3% during the course of last year. I wouldn't expect any fundamental shift away from where we've been getting it currently.

And then just one final question. In terms of the market growth, if you look at the real growth we have had across the market over the past, I suppose, 12 months or so that's been alluded to, give us a feel in terms of what sort of growth rates you guys are looking at going forward. I just heard you say macros (92.08) may be starting to edge out a little bit more again and population growth slowing, those sorts of things?

Yeah, I mean I wouldn't again comment specifically on growth forecast. But we would expect the business to continue to perform at a progressive growth trend. I think that what we've got to do is recognize that quarter-on-quarter and half-on-half, there will be variation. And we're still very much focused on driving the turnaround, then it's across a five year plan.

So I think that's our focus. The early results are encouraging during the course of this particular year compared to where we were the previous year. But there is still a significant amount of work to be done in the organization in order to bring about sustainable change.
Okay, that's everything. Thank you.
And your next question comes from David Cooke from RBS. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, all. A couple of quick questions if I may. What were your food sales like in Coles? I suppose the other way of asking the question is when you look at sales growing ahead of your food sales during the half or because of the reinvestment that you had after (93.24) the growth in the food section (93.25) that's been ?
Well, again, we don't break out the overall growth in each of those individual areas but I'm pleased to sort of say we're seeing growth both in food and indeed in liquor.

Because you started your – you've probably got further ahead in your restructuring of the liquor side catch (93.45) the food side, so I'm trying to see whether the the sense (93.46) that you've got there is a big incentive (93.48) that we should be seeing over the next six to 12 months in the supermarket side of it?

Yeah, I am not sure that that's the case. I mean clearly there is a number of factors that need to be improved in food but actually liquor needs to have some fairly significant change as well. There's been investment in price to drive further value both in food and liquor and it's getting encouraging results in both categories.
Ian, you talked about improving your basket sizes and your foot traffic, can you give us an indication as to how much has improved ?

Again we've seen sort of progress in each of them. It's something which is encouraging. I think that our total numbers will indicate that we've seen a growth quarter-on-quarter across the year. And that's the real number to focus on. But I think the reason we try to give indication on that is that it's a combination of factors that are heading in the right direction that's driving that and not just any particular one aspect to it. But I won't be breaking it down into individual areas.

Would it be true to say then if you're attracting more customers into your stores, that that's probably a better growth profile that you are getting market side or is it the fact that your stalwart Coles customers are actually getting – actually buying more?

It's a combination of both. I think that the – when we look to the overall plan of improvement for Coles and how we might drive change, we fully recognize that there is a strong fresh food opportunity. And we had a number of customers coming through our doors already but we probably weren't giving them the complete offer to encourage them to buy from us and that's what we've been working on trying to improve. And that's been beneficial in terms of growing the basket size.

If I look at the margin improvement that you've got today, to what extent have you been able to capture the low hanging fruit, and to what extent is the growth profile or the improvement in Coles' profile over the next 12 months going to be increasingly more difficult?

Well, it hasn't felt that easy in the first 12 months, to be perfectly honest. But the next 12 months are obviously going to be challenging as a step on in expectation. The first couple of years are about building a solid foundation and that's what we continue to do.

If there have been opportunities to capture low hanging fruit as you describe it, we've endeavored to take it. But it's a multifaceted change program we're developing and getting consistent change in improvements will take time. But we're very much focused on it. It's an encouraging start. But we've certainly got a lot more work to do.

I have a question for Stewart on the resources side. Stewart, the increase in your expectations of Curragh sales for FY '10, is that all contracted or is some of that going to be sold on spot? Is that increase a matter of being (96.42) sold on spot?
No, that's all contracted with our existing customers.
So now your production expectation fully match your contracted volume?
Yeah, that – sort of within 100 or couple of 100,000 tons, yes.
Okay, thank you.

David, I think that just reflects in many ways a view now that customer will take a bit more of what they committed to than they might have three or six – we might have thought they would three or six months ago.
Okay. So it – would I be correct in saying, the previous guidance was probably towards the low end of contracted range, the new guidance is probably towards the upper end of contracted range?

I wouldn't read that into it at all. Basically, we are still taking a pretty conservative view of the market place going forward. It's early days in terms of the recovery, and I think our numbers should reflect that.

What we've done – what we were pleased with – and Stewart said this I think in April, what we were pleased with was the level of commitments we did get from our customers at a time when markets were really disruptive and steel production was down. And that was because they value Curragh as a supplier – they have a very high value on Curragh as a supplier. And I think that that puts the business in good shape.
Do you sell any volume on spot?

Not per se. The only time we've sold into the spot market was the last quarter in the last financial year, particularly as a result of what was happening in the PCI market where we were struggling to place all our production into that market. We had to sell some coal into the spot market and divert some PCI into the export thermal coal market as well.
Now would you look to sell spot this year if pricing continues to improve?

Look, our philosophy is very much to look after our existing customer base. We have got great customers and 85% of those are in the North Asia, South Asia market place. And we see our obligations to them first. If there is excess capacity above that then clearly other options are available.
Okay, thank you.
And your next question comes from David Errington from Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.
Hi, Richard.
Hi, Dave. How are you doing?
Good, thanks. Gresham, when are you going to write the other 122 off?

I suspect we won't have to. But only time will tell. What – there's a couple of things on the Gresham Private Equity. On Fund 1, as you say – as Terry mentioned has been a really terrific investment. We did account for Fund 1 differently. We are counting Funds 2 and 3 differently to Fund 1 where they are mark to market each quarter. Fund 1, we kept that the lower of costs to realizable value.

And so you'll get some movement as the Fund – quarterly as the Fund looks at current carrying value at any particular time and that reflects pay-in multiples and current trading additions and whatever. So we've got a mix of investments in Fund 2. Some of those are looking very good. Some of those are being challenged in the current economic environment. But I'm still confident that ultimately, investment in that will be a good investment for our shareholders.

But I've heard that – I've been hearing, I don't know if it's true or not, but I'm hearing that Barminco, Witchery and Noel Leeming are going on on flats (100.19), I don't know about the others, but...

Let me tell you that all of those businesses – you're completely wrong. Witchery is performing exceptionally well, Barminco is on track, and Noel Leeming, I mean, Noel Leeming's been part of the New Zealand economy and that economy has been difficult but in recent times Noel Leeming's been going well as well.

Richard, when – I mean, you know what I'm going to ask you, I mean, you're a top ten or twenty company – diversified company, focused now on retail, coal assets, got a range of other assets, why are you doing discretion private equity fund cuts? I mean, why bother? I mean, you've got 60 million here, you've got 122 million, I mean the 60 million loss is your share of the equity, I mean, that (100.12) has probably lost four times that if you look at the debt that has to be written off and the non-equity value of your part or the equity value your partner. Why do that? (101:21)
So, David, if you'd been given a chance to invest $100 million and got 27% internal rate of return on it – annualized internal rate of return on that investment, would you do it?
I might do it directly but I wouldn't do it via Wesfarmers.
Well, why wouldn't we do it for our shareholders?
Because we don't – shareholders don't invest in Wesfarmers for you to do that.
They invest in Wesfarmers to make a decent return on their investment and -
But you're not a private equity fund now, you're a public listed company now with a large retail business et cetera, et cetera.

We have a degree of influence in these funds. We actually think the exposure to the whole private equity thing and these businesses is good for us. We second employees into Gresham. Terry and I and now Tim Bult sit on investment committee. And it gives us a window into other businesses. So we think there is other benefits but ultimately the reason we do it is because we think we'll make a decent financial return and we've had the capacity to do it.
I suppose we'll agree to disagree.
Yeah, that's -
The bottom line is that if I was an investor, I would certainly want my Managing Director focusing on improving Coles rather than investing in Barminco, but anyway, I'll move on.

Insurance, I've never seen the core ratio of Wesfarmers insurance business being above 100%. And now I do – what's happening in the insurance underwriting business – I mean I know it's tough but Wesfarmers always used to pride itself, no matter how tough the market was, you'd always have a core in the very low 90s. But now you're well above 100, I mean, that to me is a situation that is very alarming.
I'll let Rob answer it. It's certainly not a performance that any of us is happy with, but I think the factors that impacted that business this year clearly indicate why it's happened.

Yeah, David, Rob here. You're right that since 2004 since the collapse of HIH and the introduction of APRA regulation and so forth in Australia, Australian insurers have enjoyed very strong combined operating ratios as a result of that. That period also coincided with a period of fairly benign weather.

If you go back a bit longer than that, you go back to '99, 2000 you'll see that our ratios were up at that level as were Lumley's and indeed the rest of the markets were quite a bit higher. And what we're finding as I said earlier, the weather related events over the last 12 months have essentially resulted in 10 times the level of claims that we have experienced over the last 15 year average.

So when a factor like that happens when you have the bush fires coinciding with significant weather events particularly along the East Coast of Australia, as an insurer, it's pretty hard to hide from that. And I think you'll find other Australian property insurers, short-tail insurers are being exposed in very similar ways.
So it's one-off, Rob, it's not – you haven't increased the risk of your writings have you? Or it's purely just one-off weather events?

No that's – the weather events are a very key part of it. I did mention – I have mentioned over the last year that we believe that the two Lumley businesses can perform better than they had done. That is not the key driver of performance this year. The key driver is weather-related events. We've signaled a strong improvement in performance in our New Zealand business and we're working on very similar strategies to improve performance in Australia.

And, David, just as part of that, you will have seen recently we exited builders warranty insurance in New South Wales and that's part of that sort of operational review that Rob has talked about which has been really extensive across the business.
Okay. Launa must be saying, gee whiz, why isn't anyone asking me questions, ask a bit for Target and Kmart.
She's happy, David.
I'm fine, David. You don't have to ask anything.

Launa, what's your view towards the upcoming year, particularly the cycle post stimulus? What are you going to be doing for the business going forward? Because this result would have to be an all-time record, fantastic outcome, but how do you face 2010 having to stand up and compare against this?

Look David I think it is going to be a challenging one. And we're playing it okay in the sense that we're going according to plan at the moment in the beginning of the new financial year. But we do recognize that December is going to be quite a tough month due to the fact that there was a big stimulus program last year. The only thing I can say is that really applies to all retailers and the stimulus package went out to everyone and of course as well for this March, April period.

The thing that we did well is we were able to respond to it, particularly in March and April, because we did a lot of analysis on what had happened in December and then went in and bought product accordingly. We're still really managing our inventory levels very tightly and keeping a strong focus on our costs. But also recognizing that some of our categories are performing well and we're going to continue to make sure that we're well-stocked of those.
So, you, but you – I mean it's going to be pretty hard coming up against this. Have you got any idea what the stimulus gave you, or are you just not prepared to say?
We do have an idea and I will be quite honest and say we did benefit from it. And that's what we're going to have to work out as to how we sum up those figures?

Richard, finally, when I look at this result, I see some good, some average and some below average. And there's some below average here that basically you've got to question what the future is for them being part of the Wesfarmers business mix. I won't name those but you could probably work out that there's been some pretty ordinary performance here. Why – are you going to – why persist with some businesses?

And I suppose my question is the concern that I've got it is that you've become so big, so diverse now, so many people are focused on Coles. I mean the questions today, probably 70%, are on Coles. Hardly any questions are on the non-retail business which gives an indication of the investor interest. In my experience with companies that get little interest in them, those businesses are the ones that really do deteriorate. How are you going to ensure that those businesses don't deteriorate and continue to detract from what could be an important turnaround?
Yeah, David, we're certainly not happy with the performance of some of the businesses last year. We understand the factors that led to that, but you can't be happy with the outcomes.
Some of those factors were within your control, some were without your control, but there's some that were within your control.
Yeah.

That's what I'm concerned about. And Wesfarmers management used to be all over it, and then when you start getting things that sneak through, it just means that there's probably been a bit of lack of focus. And that's where I'm hard on aggression, is when you get these issues coming out, it just shows that management can't be in 100 places at one time.

Yeah. See, that's where I will disagree with you. I think if you look – firstly, I reckon, the diversified nature of the Group for the last 12 months has been a real benefit. We've got cash flows coming in from even the businesses that didn't perform as well as we may have liked to generate cash. And in the environment we've been in that's really good.

If you also look at what we've done in some of the non-retail businesses in the last couple of years, we significantly increased production capacity at CSBP and we continue to do that. We've commenced the Blackwater Creek Diversion at Curragh and as Stewart said, we're looking at how we can increase production not only at Curragh but also at Bengalla. The ongoing improvement growth in industrial and safety division continues. The insurance business has continued to acquire small businesses, and we've commenced LNG production at – in the energy division.

So we're doing a lot in each these businesses. And because of the Wesfarmers model we actually can focus on them. So I don't try and run these businesses, we have very good reporting systems and processes in the Group. We have very good governance processes in the Group.

We have excellent executives running these businesses. And I'm quite satisfied that in fact we'll get as good or better outcome from these businesses within Wesfarmers as we would outside the Group because of that business model.

And I think a really good example is the insurance division. Because the insurance division is in the Wesfarmers Group, Rob has had the capacity this year to effect the sort of changes that will make a meaningful long-term difference to insurers, whereas if he was a separately listed company, he'd have everyone on his back about short-term earnings outcomes. And so I think, I'm a strong supporter of the business model and we'll continue to support each of the businesses in the Group. We will be after decent returns on capital from all of them, and we'll be allocating new capital where we'll get the best returns.
Thanks, Richard.
Thanks, David.
And your next question comes from Richard Barwick from Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.
Hi, Richard.
Hi, Richard.

Couple of questions on Coles for starters. Just thinking, looking across the slides here, there is lots of data out there about investment in stores and basically I guess putting more money into the business. I can see clearly there's some scope for working capital improvements. But can you talk a little bit – or, Ian, perhaps talk a little bit about actual cost-reduction possibilities from here? For example, are there any further potential to reduce head count in head office or is that as far as it's going to go?

I think the head count has been fairly significantly reduced already in head office. We're always looking at each of the cost lines that we have to see how we might improve, and some of those will be how can we get more efficiencies in terms of people costs. The reality is we're still adding value in terms of jobs, as we develop more stores and expand existing ones.

You obviously look at each of the individual cost lines, whether it's supply chain, whether it's wasted mark-downs in stores or rostering in stores as well. But it's – it's about driving efficiency in order to improve ratios and improve the revenue line as much as looking for cost-reduction opportunities. But where there are opportunities, we're identifying them and we'll put programs in place to take them.
Margin expansion from here will be more a leverage issue rather than actual elimination of costs?

I think it'll be a combination of both if I'm honest. I think that there are ways in which we can improve our efficiency and reduce our costs. We can't just do it just by simply taking money out, otherwise the business will go back to the way that it was. This business needs re-generation, and it needs that level of focus. And we need to make sure that our managers have got the effective tools and investment to do that job. That's why we've invested quite heavily in equipment where it's required.

But actually there should be efficiency that comes out the back of that. If you're going to put in self-scanning it helps the customer, actually helps the cost line as well, as an example. So, you're looking at a pre-granular level of detail and you will see those improvements come through over time. But as I said before, there are a myriad of challenges that we face. We still face some now, but it's an encouraging short-term early performance.

Okay. And thinking about some of the actions of Woolworths in terms of their driving loyalty through their everyday rewards card, frequent flyers, et cetera, et cetera. Are we going to see something from you guys re fly-bys?

I mean, loyalty schemes, where they're run by retailers, are an element in the marketing mix. They're not a primary determinant of store choice in my experience. I mean value and convenience are significantly higher. So we were looking to see how loyalty plays out in relation to developing our overall marketing initiatives and programs to customers and we've got one or two trials in place at the moment.
Okay.

Our general view on it is, and experience is that customers do tend to prefer in-loyalty schemes some form of cash reward as opposed to payments in-kind. And I think the docket program that was developed on fuel is a very good example of that.

A question for Launa, just thinking currency – I know, Richard, you said before you felt like the impact was a little bit overstated, perhaps upside and downside. So I'd just be interested to get a view there on how the average currency for this current financial year FY '10 will compare to FY '09, presumably you've got hedging through to the end of the year or very close to it by now?

We do take currency. We take currency as we go along right the way through, as we did last financial year. Where we're sitting at the moment for the first half of this financial year, it will be at a dollar rate less than it was for the last financial year. But also understanding that the forward cover even for the back half of the financial year we've just had was less than it was for the previous year as well. So it's just something we have to manage and – but we do take a forward cover because we really do strongly believe that we're in the game of retailing and not in the game of speculation.

And, Richard and/or Terry, just thinking about dividends, I mean, it was a nice surprise to see the $1.10 today rather than the $1.00. How should we be thinking about this fairly wordy dividend policy that you gave earlier in the year. Are you thinking more payout ratio or are you thinking growth year-on-year?

Well, we're actually thinking in the way the words to describe it, Richard. Yeah, we will look at what our cash balances are, what capital expenditure requirements are, how we're feeling about the business, level of franking credits, et cetera. The reason it is higher is because we had stronger cash generation than we thought. And I think the outlook is better than when we revised the dividend policy, but obviously we're still being cautious.

We do understand that shareholders would like stable and if possible growing dividends, and that's what we will endeavor to achieve, but. And we do have some volatility in some of our businesses. We know that it's beneficial to pass franking credits onto shareholders as quickly as we can, but our number one priority will be our balance sheet.
But presumably you wouldn't have moved to the extra $0.10 this year unless you were pretty confident you could surpass that next year?
I'm not going to comment on that.
Okay. Thank you.
Thanks.
And your next question comes from Michael Burn from Souls Funds Management (117:25). Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, Richard. My question requires an observation, I refer you to some research earlier this last week by the CFB Resources, it must be (117.36) a guy by the name of Paul McTaggart. And it relates to Felix Resources and you've got a nice table in there showing what this entity is paying for Felix Resources. And to summarize it for you, they're paying $3.2 billion of enterprise value for an operation barely a quarter of the size of your coal business. And the other observation I'd make, if I look at...
I'd probably take 12, if someone wants to start with it, Michael.

Sure. Now, the problem I have is that I as an investor in Wesfarmers see analysts tell me, broking houses tell me, your business is sometimes worth 2 billion, sometimes worth 3 billion, and now I see a transaction which is telling me it could be worth 12 billion. So I guess, if I also then go and look at Wesfarmers as a company and I had to strip out the coal business, I've got EBIT in the non-coal business growing at around about 10 – 8 to 10% a year. And I think it's pretty defensive, recurring kind of EBIT that (118.33).

Put the coal business in there and I've got to contend with earnings some years going up 30%, some years the EBIT's falling 20%, like we got next year. And I guess that gets to the heart of, to state the obvious, things like what you list as appropriate pay for that earnings stream, the cost of capital and hence the value of the business. So I think this question has been asked in a round about way before.

But I'm thinking specifically with – in relation to coal. I get the sense that coal assets somehow have now mysteriously garnered a significant uplift in value in the last six months. And I'll also wager that fast-forward 12-18 months, a lot of this value would have been proven to be very transient I think. How much – and here's the question, I think you know where the question is going – I mean, how much impetus is there, how much in the imperative do you feel, that the Board feel, to feed the ducks while they're quacking, as it were?

Well, on any of our businesses, Michael, we always have a view that if someone comes up and says they're prepared to pay a price which on an after-tax basis is more than we think the business is worth, then we'll have a conversation with them. And that has happened in the past, it happened with our rural division and it happened with the rail joint venture we had. But that's – but it doesn't happen that often. And I quite deliberately said after tax because for a number of our businesses selling them would create a significant capital gains tax issue which is a big value leakage...
Right.

...to our shareholders. So I guess the comfort I can give you is, we don't have a closed mind to this thing – to these sort of things. But the division you're talking about specifically, I think if you step back and look at the resources sector for the next 10 to 20 years, having highly efficient low-cost open-cut coal mines, with the position Australia is in with the growing economies of India and China and other Asian economies, I think they're going to be pretty good assets to own. So, like any of our businesses, if someone wants to acquire them they'll have to pay a price that we think is attractive to do it.
So I'm assuming spinning them off also has capital gains tax implications.
Spinning off has other implications.
Okay.
Both for shareholders and for the Group that we'd have to take into account.

Right. I guess I'm just trying to vent my – express some frustration at the fact that I see a business here – and not immaterial in the context of a 30, 33% enterprise value of the overall Group, valuation going from a couple of billion dollars to $10 billion. It's quite difficult to – it becomes quite unworkable sometimes.
And it does move our share price around a bit, but over time it's been a fabulous investment for Wesfarmers' shareholders.
All right. Thanks for your thoughts, Richard.
Thanks.
And there are no further questions at this time so I'll turn the conference back to Mr. Goyder. Please go ahead.

Well, thank you all, I know it's a busy time for you at the moment in reporting season. If you've got any follow-up questions come through Tanya and we look forward to catching up with you in the near future. Thanks.
